subject: RE: [junit] Starter
msgSnippet: ... Points: * What coding conventions do you use at your company? The class name adder doesn t fit with any I know of. (Likewise adderTest) * I d add a
messageBody:
At 09:53 AM 10/01/02, you wrote:

>Ok I'll make a deal,
>
>I have started on a project recently using junit, basically I am supposed
>to provide support and documentation to fellow work colleagues on the use
>of junit, the idea being that more people will start using
>junit. Basically its my job to navigate many of the potential
>problems. Anyhow the problem I had when beginning with junit was I found
>that a lot of the documentaion had holes in it. So I've attached here a
>document which describes how to write your first junit test (it assumes
>junit is already installed). Maybe you will find it useful, and any
>feedback would be appreciated, Nic.


Points:
* What coding conventions do you use at your company? The class name
"adder" doesn't fit with any I know of. (Likewise adderTest)
* I'd add a constructor to adder, if only for clarity and to avoid confusion.
* Add setUp, tearDown to the example test - I know you're striving for
clarity here, but I don't think they're so complicated as to confuse
things, and they are essential.
* I assume you'll later explain suites etc. Good idea for leaving them out.


Nice simple test, though. An explicit example with a bug in it might be a
good idea.

Jim



--

* Jim Cheesman *

voice is it disgruntled?
